But if you knew to whom you show this honour,
how true a gentleman you send relief,
how dear a lover of my Lord your husband,
I know you would be prouder of the work
than customary bounty can enforce you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I never did repent for doing good,
nor shall not now: for in companions
that do converse and waste the time together,
whose souls do bear an egal yoke of love,
there must be needs a like proportion
of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit;
which makes me think that this Anthonio
being the bosom lover of my Lord,
must needs be like my Lord. If it be so,
How little is the cost I have bestowed
in purchasing the semblance of my soul;
From out the state of hellish cruelty,
This comes too near the praising of myself,
Therefore no more of it: here other things
Lorenso I commit into your hands,
The husbandry and manage of my house,
Until my Lords return: for mine own part
I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow,
To live in prayer and contemplation,
Only attended by Nerrissa here,
Until her husband and my Lords return,
There is a Monastery two miles off,
And there we will abide. I do desire you
not to deny this imposition,
the which my love and some necessity
now lays upon you.

sp.speaker: Lorens.
sp.l: Madam, with all my heart,
I shall obey you in all fair commands.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: My people do already know my mind,
And will acknowledge you and Iessica
in place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
So fare you well till we shall meet again.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: I wish your Ladyship all hearts content.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I thank you for your wish, and am well pleased
to wish it back on you: fare you well Iessica.
Now Balthaser, as I have ever found thee honest true,
So let me find thee still: take this same letter,
and use thou all the endeavour of a man,
In speed to Mantua, see thou render this
into my cousin hands Doctor Belario,
And look what notes and garments he doth give thee,
bring them I pray thee with imagined speed
unto the Tranect, to the common Ferry
which trades to Venice; waste no time in words
but get thee gone, I shall be there before thee.

sp.speaker: Baltha.
sp.l: Madam, I go with all convenient speed.

sp.speaker: Portia
sp.l: Come on Nerrissa, I have work in hand
That you yet know not of; we will see our husbands
before they think of us?

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: Shall they see us?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: They shall Nerrissa: but in such a habit,
that they shall think we are accomplished
with that we lack; I will hold thee any wager
when we are both accoutred like young men,
I will prove the prettier fellow of the two,
and wear my dagger with the braver grace,
and speak between the change of man and boy,
with a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps
into a manly stride; and speak of frays
like a fine bragging youth: and tell quaint lies
how honourable Ladies sought my love,
which I denying, they fell sick and died.
I could not do withal: then I will repent,
and wish for all that, that I had not killed them;
And twenty of these puny lies I will tell,
that men shall swear I have discontinued school
above a twelvemonth: I have within my mind
a thousand raw tricks of these bragging Iacks,
which I will practise.

sp.speaker: Nerriss.
sp.l: Why, shall we turn to men?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: Fie, what a question is that,
if thou wert never a lewd interpreter:
But come, I will tell thee all my whole device
when I am in my coach, which stays for us
at the Park gate; and therefore haste away,
for we must measure twenty miles today.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Yes truly, for look you, the sins of the Father are to
be laid upon the children, therefore I promise you, I fear you, I
was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of
the matter: therefore be a good cheer, for truly I think you are
damned, there is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and
that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.

sp.speaker: Iessica.
sp.p: And what hope is that I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Marry you may partly hope that your Father got you
not, that you are not the Jews daughter.

sp.speaker: Iessica.
sp.p:
That were a kind of bastard hope indeed, so the sins
of my mother should be visited upon me.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and
mother: thus when I shun Scilla your father, I fall into Caribdis
your mother; well, you are gone both ways.

sp.speaker: Iessica.
sp.p: I shall be saved by my husband, he hath made me a Christian?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Truly the more to blame he, we were Christians enough
before, in as many as could well live one by another: this making
of Christians will raise the price of Hogs, if we grow all to be pork
eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.p: I will tell my husband Launcelet what you say, here he come?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p:
I shall grow jealous of you shortly Launcelet, if you thus
get my wife into corners?

sp.speaker: Iessica.
sp.p:
Nay, you need not fear us Lorenzo, Launcelet and I are
out, he tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven, because
I am a Jews daughter: and he says you are no good member of
the common-wealth, for in converting Jews to Christians, you
raise the price of pork.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p:
I shall answer that better to the common-wealth than
you can the getting up of the Negroes belly: the Moore is with
child by you Launcelet?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
It is much that the Moore should be more than reason:
but if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more
than I took her for.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p:
How every fool can play upon the word, I think the
best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow
commendable in none only but Parrots: go in sirrah, bid them
prepare for dinner?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: That is done sir, they have all stomachs?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p:
Goodly Lord what a wit snapper are you, then bid them
prepare dinner?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: That is done too sir, only cover is the word.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: Will you cover then sir?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Not so sir neither, I know my duty.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p:
Yet more quarrelling with occasion, wilt thou show
the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant; I pray thee understand a
plain man in his plain meaning: go to thy fellows, bid them
cover the table, serve in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
For the table sir, it shall be served in, for the meat sir, it
shall be covered, for your coming in to dinner sir, why let it be as
humours and conceits shall govern.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: O dear discretion, how his words are suited,
The fool hath planted in his memory
an Army of good words, and I do know
a many fools that stand in better place,
garnished like him, that for a tricksy word
defy the matter: how cheerest thou Iessica,
And now good sweet say thy opinion,
How dost thou like the Lord Bassanios wife?

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: Past all expressing, it is very meet
the Lord Bassanio live an upright life
For having such a blessing in his Lady,
he finds the joys of heaven here on earth,
And if on earth he do not mean it, it
in reason he should never come to heaven?
Why, if two Gods should play some heavenly match,
and on the wager lay two earthly women,
And Portia one: there must be something else
pawned with the other, for the poor rude world
hath not her fellow.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Even such a husband
hast thou of me, as she is for wife.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: Nay, but ask my opinion too of that?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I will anon, first let us go to dinner?

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: No pray thee, let it serve for table talk,
Then how so mere thou speakest among other things,
I shall digest it?

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: Well, I will set you forth.

div2.stage: Enter the Duke, the Magnificoes, Anthonio, Bassanio, and Gratiano.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What, is Anthonio here?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Ready, so please your grace?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am sorry for thee, thou art come to answer
a stony adversary, an inhumane wretch,
uncapable of pity, void, and empty
from any dram of mercy.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I have heard
your grace hath taken great pains to qualify
his rigorous course; but since he stands obdurate,
And that no lawful means can carry me
out of his envies reach, I do oppose
my patience to his fury, and am armed
to suffer with a quietness of spirit,
the very tyranny and rage of his.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Go one and call the Iew into the Court.

sp.speaker: Salerio.
sp.l: He is ready at the door, he comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Make room, and let him stand before our face.
Shylocke the world thinks, and I think so too
that thou but leadest this fashion of thy malice
to the last hour of act, and then it is thought
thou wilt show thy mercy and remorse more strange,
than is thy strange apparent cruelty;
and where thou now exacts the penalty,
which is a pound of this poor Merchants flesh,
thou wilt not only lose the forfeiture,
but touched with human gentleness and love:
Forgive a moiety of the principal,
glancing an eye of pity on his losses
that have of late so huddled on his back,
Enough to press a royal Merchant down;
And pluck commiseration of this states
from brassy bosoms and rough hearts of flints,
from stubborn Turks, and Tartars never trained
to offices of tender courtesy:
We all expect a gentle answer Jew?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: I have possessed your grace of what I purpose,
and by our holy Sabbath have I sworn
to have the due and forfeit of my bond,
if you deny it, let the danger light
upon your charter and your City's freedom?
You will ask me why I rather choose to have
a weight of carrion flesh, than to receive
three thousand ducats: I will not answer that?
But say it is my humour, is it answered?
What if my house be troubled with a Rat,
and I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats
to have it baned? what, are you answered yet?
Some men there are love not a gaping pig?
Some that are mad if they behold a Cat?
And others when the bagpipe sings in the nose,
cannot contain their urine for affection.
Masters of passion sways it to the mood
of what it likes or loathes, now for your answer:
As there is no firm reason to be rendered
why he cannot abide a gaping pig?
why he a harmless necessary Cat?
why he a woollen bagpipe: but of force
must yield to such inevitable shame,
as to offend himself being offended:
So can I give no reason, nor I will not,
more than a lodged hate, and a certain loathing
I bear Anthonio, that I follow thus
a loosing suit against him? are you answered?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This is no answer thou unfeeling man,
to excuse the currant of thy cruelty?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: I am not bound to please thee with my answers?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Do all men kill the things they do not love?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Every offence is not a hate at first?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I pray you think you question with the Jew,
you may as well go stand upon the Beach
and bid the main flood bate his usual height,
you may as well use question with the Wolf
the Ewe bleak for the Lamb:
You may as well forbid the mountain of Pines
to wag their high tops, and to make no noise
when they are fretten with the gusts of heaven:
You may as well do anything most hard
as seek to soften that than which what is harder:
his Jewish heart? therefore I do beseech you
make no more offers, use no farther means,
but with all brief and plain convenience
let me have judgment, and the Jew his will?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: For thy three thousand ducats here is six?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: If every ducat in six thousand ducats
were in six parts, and every part a ducat,
I would not draw them, I would have my bond?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How shalt thou hope for mercy rendering none?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: What judgment shall I dread doing no wrong?
you have among you many a purchased slave,
which like your Asses, and your Dogs and Mules
you use in abject and in slavish parts,
because you bought them, shall I say to you,
let them be free, marry them to your heirs?
why sweat they under burthens, let their beds
be made as soft as yours, and let their palates
be seasoned with such viands, you will answer
the slaves are ours, so do I answer you:
The pound of flesh which I demand of him
is dearly bought, as mine and I will have it:
if you deny me, fie upon your Law,
there is no force in the decrees of Venice:
I stand for judgment, answer, shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Upon my power I may dismiss this Court,
unless Bellario a learned Doctor,
whom I have sent for to determine this
Come here today?

sp.speaker: Salerio.
sp.l: My Lord, here stays without
a messenger with letters from the Doctor,
new come from Padua?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring us the letters? call the Messenger?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Good cheer Anthonio? what man, courage yet:
The Iew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all,
ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am a tainted wether of the flock,
meetest for death, the weakest kind of fruit
drops earliest to the ground, and so let me;
You cannot better be employed Bassanio,
than to live still and write mine Epitaph?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Came you from Padua from Bellario?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: From both? my Lord Bellario greets your grace?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there?

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: Not on thy soul: but on thy soul harsh Iew
thou makest thy knife keen: but no metal can,
no, not the hangman's axe bear half the keenness
of thy sharpe envy: can no prayers pearce thee?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.

sp.speaker: Gratia.
sp.l: O be thou damned, inexecrable dog,
And for thy life let justice be accused;
Thou almost makest me waver in my faith,
to hold opinion with Pythagoras,
that souls of Animals infuse themselves
into the trunks of men: Thy currish spirit
governed a Wolf, who hanged for human slaughter
even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet,
and whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam;
infused itself in thee: for thy desires
are wolfish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.l: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond,
Thou but offendest thy lungs to speak so loud:
Repair thy wit good youth, or it will fall
to cureless ruin. I stand here for law.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This letter from Bellario doth commend
a young and learned Doctor to our Court:
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: He attendeth here hard by
to know your answer whether you will admit him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: With all my heart: some three or four of you
go give him courteous conduct to this place,
mean time the Court shall hear Bellarios letter.
sp.p:
Your Grace shall understand, that at the receipt of your letter I
am very sick, but in the instant that your messenger came, in loving
visitation was with me a young Doctor of Rome, his name is
Balthazer: I acquainted him with the cause in controversy between
the Iew and Anthonio the Merchant, we turned over many books
together, he is furnished with my opinion, which bettered with
his own learning, the greatness whereof I cannot enough commend,
comes with him at my importunity, to fill up your graces
request in my stead. I beseech you let his lack of years be no impediment
to let him lack a reverend estimation, for I never knew
so young a body with so old a head: I leave him to your gracious
acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You hear the learned Bellario what he writes,
and here I take it is the doctor come.
Give me your hand, come you from old Bellario?

sp.speaker: Portia.
sp.l: I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are welcome, take your place:
are you acquainted with the difference
that holds this present question in the Court.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I am informed thoroughly of the cause,
which is the Merchant here? and which the Iew?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Anthonio and old Shylocke, both stand forth.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is your name Shylocke?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Shylocke is my name.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow,
yet in such rule, that the Venetian law
cannot impugn you as you do proceed.
You stand within his danger, do you not.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Aye, so he says.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Do you confess the bond?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then must the Iew be merciful.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: On what compulsion must I, tell me that.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The quality of mercy is not strained,
it droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven
upon the place beneath: it is twice blessed,
it blesseth him that gives, and him that takes,
it is mightiest in the mightiest, it becomes
the throned Monarch better than his crown.
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,
the attribute to awe and majesty,
wherein doth sit the dread and fear of Kings:
but mercy is above this sceptred sway,
it is enthroned in the hearts of Kings,
it is an attribute to God himself;
and earthly power doth then show likest gods
when mercy seasons justice: therefore Iew,
though justice be thy plea, consider this,
that in the course of justice, none of us
should see salvation: we do pray for mercy,
and that same prayer, doth teach us all to render
the deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much
to mitigate the justice of thy plea,
which if thou follow, this strict Court of Venice
must needs give sentence against the Merchant there.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: My deeds upon my head, I crave the law,
the penalty and forfeit of my bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is he not able to discharge the money?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Yes, here I tender it for him in the Court,
yea, twice the sum, if that will not suffice,
I will be bound to pay it ten times over
on forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart,
if this will not suffice, it must appear
that malice bears down truth. And I beseech you
wrest once the law to your authority,
to do a great right, do a little wrong,
and curb this cruel devil of his will.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It must not be, there is no power in Venice
can altar a decree established:
it will be recorded for a precedent,
and many an error by the same example
will rush into the state, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: A Daniell come to judgment: yea a Daniell.
O wise young Judge how I do honour thee.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I pray you let me look upon the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Here it is most reverend doctor, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Shylocke there is thrice thy money offered thee.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven,
shall I lay perjury upon my soul?
Not not for Venice.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why this bond is forfeit,
and lawfully by this the Iew may claim
a pound of flesh, to be by him cut off
nearest the Merchants heart: be merciful,
take thrice thy money, bid me tear the bond.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: When it is paid, according to the tenure.
It doth appear you are a worthy judge,
you know the law, your exposition
hath been most sound: I charge you by the law,
whereof you are a well deserving pillar,
proceed to judgment: by my soul I swear,
there is no power in the tongue of man
to alter me, I stay here on my Bond,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Most heartily I do beseech the Court
to give the judgment.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why then thus it is,
you must prepare your bosom for his knife.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: O noble Judge, O excellent young man.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: For the intent and purpose of the law
hath full relation to the penalty,
which here appeareth due upon the bond.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: It is very true: O wise and upright Judge,
how much more elder art thou than thy looks.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore lay bare your bosom.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Aye, his breast,
so says the bond, doth it not noble Judge?
Nearest his heart, those are the very words.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is so, are there balance here to weigh the flesh?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I have them ready.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Have by some Surgeon Shylocke on your charge,
to stop his wounds, lest he do bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Is it so nominated in the bond?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is not so expressed, but what of that?
It were good you do so much for charity.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I cannot find it, it is not in the bond.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You Merchant, have you anything to say?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But little; I am armed and well prepared,
give me your hand Bassanio, fare you well,
grieve not that I am fallen to this for you:
for herein Fortune shows herself more kind
than is her custom: it is still her use
to let the wretched man outlive his wealth,
to view with hollow eye and wrinkled brow
an age of poverty: from which lingering penance
of such misery doth she cut me off.
Commend me to your honourable wife,
tell her the process of Anthonios end,
say how I loved you, speak me fair in death:
and when the tale is told, bid her be judge
whether Bassanio had not once a love:
Repent but you that you shall lose your friend
and he repents not that he pays your debt.
For if the Iew do cut but deep enough,
I will pay it instantly with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Anthonio, I am married to a wife
which is as dear to me as life itself,
but life itself, my wife, and all the world,
are not with me esteemed above thy life.
I would lose all, I sacrifice them all
here to this devil, to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your wife would give you little thanks for that
if she were by to hear you make the offer.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: I have a wife who I protest I love,
I would she were in heaven, so she could
entreat some power to change this currish Iew.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: It is well you offer it behind her back,
the wish would make else an unquiet house.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: These be the christian husbands, I have a daughter
would any of the stock of Barrabas
had been her husband, rather than a Christian.
We trifle time, I pray thee pursue sentence.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A pound of that same Merchants flesh is thine,
the Court awards it, and the law doth give it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Most rightful Judge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast,
the law allows it, and the court awards it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Most learned Judge, a sentence, come prepare.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry a little, there is something else,
this bond doth give thee here no jot of blood,
the words expressly are a pound of flesh:
take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,
but in the cutting it, if thou dost shed
one drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods
are by the laws of Venice confiscate
unto the state of Venice.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O upright Judge,
Mark Iew, O learned Judge.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Is that the law?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thyself shalt see the Act:
for as thou urgest justice, be assured
thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O learned judge, mark Iew, a learned judge.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I take this offer then, pay the bond thrice
and let the Christian go.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Here is the money.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Soft, the Iew shall have all justice, soft no haste,
he shall have nothing but the penalty.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: O Iew, an upright Judge, a learned Judge.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh,
Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more
but just a pound of flesh: if thou takest more
or less than a just pound, be it but so much
as makes it light or heavy in the substance,
or the division of the twentieth part
of one poor scruple, nay if the scale do turn
but in the estimation of a hair,
thou diest, and all thy goods are confiscate.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A second Daniell, a Daniell Iew,
now infidel I have you on the hip.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why doth the Iew pause, take thy forfeiture.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Give me my principal, and let me go.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I have it ready for thee, here it is.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He hath refused it in the open Court,
he shall have merely justice and his bond.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A Daniell still say I, a second Daniell,
I thank thee Iew for teaching me that word.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Shall I not have barely my principal?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture
to be so taken at thy peril Iew.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Why then the devil give him good of it:
I will stay no longer question.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Tarry Iew,
the law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the laws of Venice,
if it be proved against an alien,
that by direct, or indirect attempts
he seek the life of any Citizen,
the party against the which he doth contrive,
shall seize one half his goods, the other half
comes to the privy coffer of the State,
and the offenders life lies in the mercy
of the Duke only, against all other voice.
In which predicament I say thou standest:
for it appears by manifest proceeding,
that indirectly, and directly too
thou hast contrived against the very life
of the defendant: and thou hast incurred
the danger formerly by me rehearsed.
Down therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself,
and yet thy wealth being forfeit to the state,
thou hast not left the value of a cord,
therefore thou must be hanged at the states charge.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit
I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it:
for half thy wealth, it is Anthonios,
the other half comes to the general state,
which humbleness may drive unto a fine.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Aye for the state, not for Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that,
you take my house, when you do take the prop
that doth sustain my house: you take my life
when you do take the means whereby I live.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What mercy can you render him Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: A halter gratis, nothing else for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So please my Lord the Duke, and all the Court
to quit the fine for one half of his goods,
I am content: so he will let me have
the other half in use, to render it
upon his death unto the Gentleman
that lately stole his daughter.
Two things provided more, that for this favour
he presently become a Christian:
the other, that he do record a gift
here in the Court of all he dies possessed
unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He shall do this, or else I do recant
the pardon that I late pronounced here.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Art thou contented Iew? what dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Clarke, draw a deed of gift.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: I pray you give me leave to go from hence,
I am not well, send the deed after me,
and I will sign it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Get thee gone, but do it.

sp.speaker: Shy.
sp.l: In christening shalt thou have two Godfathers,
had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more,
to bring thee to the gallows, not to the font.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir I entreat you home with me to dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I humbly do desire your Grace of pardon,
I must away this night toward Padua,
and it is meet I presently set forth.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.
Anthonio, gratify this gentleman,
for in my mind you are much bound to him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend
have by your wisdom been this day acquitted
of grievous penalties, in lieu whereof,
three thousand ducats due unto the Iew
we freely cope your courteous pains withal.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And stand indebted over and above
in love and service to you ever-more.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He is well paid that is well satisfied,
and I delivering you, am satisfied,
and therein do account myself well paid,
my mind was never yet more mercenary.
I pray you know me when we meet again,
I wish you well, and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further,
take some remembrance of us as a tribute,
not as fee: grant me two things I pray you,
not to deny me, and to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You press me far, and therefore I will yield,
give me your gloves, I will wear them for your sake,
and for your love I will take this ring from you,
do not draw back your hand, I will take no more,
and you in love shall not deny me this?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This ring good sir, alas it is a trifle,
I will not shame myself to give you this?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will have nothing else but only this,
and now methinks I have a mind to it?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: There is more depends on this than on the value,
the dearest ring in Venice will I give you,
and find it out by proclamation,
only for this I pray you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I see sir you are liberal in offers,
you taught me first to beg, and now methinks
you teach me how a beggar should be answered.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife,
and when she put it on, she made me vow
that I should neither sell, nor give, nor lose it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That scuse serves many men to save their gifts,
and if your wife be not a mad woman,
and know how well I have deserved this ring,
she would not hold out enemy for ever
for giving it to me: well, peace be with you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring,
let his deservings and my love withal
be valued against your wives commandment.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Go Gratiano, run and overtake him,
give him the ring, and bring him if thou canst
unto Anthonios house, away, make haste.
Come, you and I will thither presently,
and in the morning early will we both
fly toward Belmont, come Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Enquire the Jews house out, give him this deed,
and let him sign it, we will away tonight,
and be a day before our husbands home:
this deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Fair sir, you are well overtaken:
My Lord Bassanio upon more advice,
hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat
your company at dinner.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That cannot be;
his ring I do accept most thankfully,
and so I pray you tell him: furthermore,
I pray you show my youth old Shylockes house.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: That will I do.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Sir, I would speak with you:
I will see if I can get my husbands ring
which I did make him swear to keep for ever.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thou mayst I warrant, we shall have old swearing
that they did give the rings away to men;
but we will out-face them, and out-swear them too:
away, make haste, thou knowest where I will tarry.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Come good sir, will you show me to this house.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: The moon shines bright. In such a night as this,
when the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees,
and they did make no noise, in such a night
Troylus methinks mounted the Troian walls,
and sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents
where Cressed lay that night.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: In such a night
did Thisbie fearefully overtrip the dew,
and saw the Lions shadow ere himself,
and ran dismayed away.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
stood Dido with a willow in her hand
upon the wild sea banks, and waft her Love
to come again to Carthage.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: In such a night
Medea gathered the enchanted herbs
that did renew old Eson.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
did Iessica steal from the wealthy Jew,
and with an unthrift love did run from Venice,
as far as Belmont.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: In such a night
did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well,
stealing her soul with many vows of faith,
and never a true one.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: In such a night
did pretty Iessica (like a little shrew)
slander her Love, and he forgave it her.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: I would out-night you did nobody come:
But hark, I hear the footing of a man.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: A friend?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: A friend, what friend, your name I pray you friend?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
my Mistress will before the break of day
be here at Belmont, she doth stray about
by holy crosses where she kneels and prays
for happy wedlock hours.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who comes with her?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: None but a holy Hermit and her maid:
I pray you is my Master yet returned?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: He is not, nor we have not heard from him,
But go we in I pray thee Iessica,
and ceremoniously let us prepare
some welcome for the Mistress of the house.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Sola, sola: wo ha, ho sola, sola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Sola, did you see Mister Lorenzo, and Mister Lorenzo sola, sola.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Leave hollowing man, here.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Sola, where, where?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Here?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Tell him there is a Post come from my Master, with his
horn full of good news, my Master will be here ere morning
sweet soul.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Let us in, and there expect their coming.
And yet no matter: why should we go in.
My friend Stephen, signify I pray you
within the house, your mistress is at hand,
and bring your music forth into the air.
How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank,
here will we sit, and let the sounds of music
creep in our ears soft stillness, and the night
become the touches of sweet harmony:
sit Iessica, look how the floor of heaven
is thick inlaid with patterns of bright gold,
there is not the smallest orb which thou beholdest
but in his motion like an Angel sings,
still choiring to the young eyed Cherubims;
such harmony is in immortal souls,
but whilst this muddy vesture of decay
doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it:
Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn,
with sweetest touches pearce your mistress ear,
and draw her home with music.

sp.speaker: Iessi.
sp.l: I am never merry when I hear sweet music.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: The reason is your spirits are attentive:
for do but note a wild and wanton herd
or race of youthful and unhandled colts
fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,
which is the hot condition of their blood,
if they but hear perchance a trumpet sound,
or any air of music touch their ears,
you shall perceive them make a mutual stand,
their savage eyes turned to a modest gaze,
by the sweet power of music: therefore the Poet
did fain that Orpheus drew trees, stones, and floods.
Since naught so stockish hard and full of rage,
but music for the time doth change his nature,
the man that hath no music in himself,
nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds,
is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils,
the motions of his spirit are dull as night,
and his affections dark as Terebus:
let no such man be trusted: mark the music.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That light we see is burning in my hall:
how far that little candle throws his beams,
so shines a good deed in a naughty world.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: When the moon shone we did not see the candle?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: So doth the greater glory dim the less,
a substitute shines brightly as a King
until a King be by, and then his state
empties itself, as doth an inland brooke
into the main of waters: music hark.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: It is your music Madam of the house?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Nothing is good I see without respect,
methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Silence bestows that virtue on it Madam?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The Crow doth sing as sweetly as the Lark
when neither is attended: and I think
the Nightingale if she should sing by day
when every Goose is cackling, would be thought
no better a Musician than the Renne?
How many things by season, seasoned are
to their right praise, and true perfection:
Peace, how the moon sleeps with Endimion,
and would not be awaked.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: That is the voice,
or I am much deceived of Portia.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: He knows me as the blind man knows the Cuckoo
by the bad voice?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Dear Lady welcome home?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We have been praying for our husbands welfare,
which speed we hope the better for our words:
are they returned?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Madam, they are not yet:
but there is come a Messenger before
to signify their coming?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Go in Nerrissa.
Give order to my servants, that they take
no note at all of our being absent hence,
nor you Lorenzo, Iessica nor you.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Your husband is at hand, I hear his trumpet,
we are no tell-tales Madam, fear you not.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: This night methinks is but the day light sick,
it looks a little paler, it is a day,
such as the day is when the sun is hid.

div2.stage: Enter Bassanio, Anthonio, Gratiano, and their followers.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: We should hold day with the Antipodes,
if you would walk in absence of the sun.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let me give light, but let me not be light,
for a light wife doth make a heavy husband,
and never be Bassanio so for me,
but God sort all: you are welcome home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I thank you Madam, give welcome to my friend,
this is the man, this is Anthonio,
to whom I am so infinitely bound.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You should in all sense be much bound to him,
for as I hear he was much bound for you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No more than I am well acquitted of.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, you are very welcome to our house:
it must appear in other ways than words,
therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong,
i'faith I gave it to the Judges Clarke,
would he were gelded that had it for my part,
since you do take it Love so much at heart.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: A quarrel ho already, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring
that she did give me, whose posy was
for all the world like Cutlers poetry
upon a knife, Love me, and leave me not.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: What talk you of the posy or the value:
You swore to me when I did give you,
that you would wear it till your hour of death,
and that it should lie with you in your grave,
though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,
you should have been respective and have kept it.
Gave it a Judges Clarke: no Gods my Judge
the Clarke will never wear hair on his face that had it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: He will, and if he live to be a man.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: Aye, if a woman live to be a man.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Now by this hand I gave it to a youth,
a kind of boy, a little scrubbed boy,
no higher than thyself, the Judges Clarke,
a prating boy that begged it as a fee,
I could not for my heart deny it him.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You were to blame, I must be plain with you,
to part so slightly with your wives first gift,
a thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger,
and so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
I gave my Love a ring, and made him swear
never to part with it, and here he stands:
I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it,
nor pluck it from his finger, for the wealth
that the world masters. Now in faith Gratiano
you give your wife too unkind a cause of grief,
if it were to me I should be mad at it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Why I were best to cut my left hand off,
and swear I lost the ring defending it.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away
unto the Judge that begged it, and indeed
deserved it too: and then the boy his Clarke
that took some pains in writing, he begged mine,
and neither man nor master would take aught
but the two rings.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What ring gave you my Lord?
Not that I hope which you received of me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: If I could add a lie unto a fault,
I would deny it: but you see my finger
hath not the ring upon it, it is gone.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Even so void is your false heart of truth.
By heaven I will never come in your bed
until I see the ring?

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Nor I in yours
till I again see mine?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Sweet Portia,
if you did know to whom I gave the ring,
if you did know for whom I gave the ring,
and would conceive for what I gave the ring,
and how unwillingly I left the ring,
when naught would be accepted but the ring,
you would abate the strength of your displeasure?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If you had known the virtue of the ring,
or half her worthiness that gave the ring,
or your own honour to contain the ring,
you would not then have parted with the ring:
what man is there so much unreasonable
if you had pleased to have defended it
with any terms of zeal: wanted the modesty
to urge the thing held as a ceremony:
Nerrissa teaches me what to believe,
I will die for it, but some woman had the ring?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: No by my honour Madam, by my soul
no woman had it, but a civil Doctor,
which did refuse three thousand ducats of me,
and begged the ring, the which I did deny him,
and suffered him to go displeased away,
even he that had held up the very life
of my dear friend. What should I say sweet Lady,
I was enforced to send it after him,
I was beset with shame and courtesy,
my honour would not let ingratitude
so much besmear it: pardon me good Lady,
for by these blessed candles of the night,
had you been there, I think you would have begged
the ring of me to give the worthy Doctor?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let not that Doctor ere come near my house
since he hath got the jewel that I loved,
and that which you did swear to keep for me,
I will become as liberal as you,
I will not deny him anything I have,
no, not my body, nor my husbands bed:
Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argos,
if you do not, if I be left alone,
now by mine honour which is yet mine own,
I will have that Doctor for mine bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: And I his Clark: therefore be well advised
how you do leave me to mine own protection.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Well do you so: let not me take him then,
for if I do, I will mar the young Clerk's pen.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I am the unhappy subject of these quarrels.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Sir, grieve not you, you are welcome notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Portia, forgive me this enforced wrong,
and in the hearing of these many friends
I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes
wherein I see myself.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Mark you but that?
In both my eyes he doubly sees himself:
In each eye one, swear by your double self,
and there is an oath of credit.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Nay, but hear me.
Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear
I never more will break an oath with thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I once did lend my body for his wealth,
which but for him that had your husbands ring
had quite miscarried. I dare be bound again,
my soul upon the forfeit, that your Lord
will never more break faith advisedly.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Then you shall be his surety: give him this,
and bid him keep it better than the other.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Here Lord Bassanio, swear to keep this ring.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: By heaven it is the same I gave the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I had it of him: pardon me Bassanio,
for by this ring the Doctor lay with me.

sp.speaker: Nerrissa.
sp.l: And pardon me my gentle Gratiano,
for that same scrubbed boy the Doctors Clarke
in lieu of this, last night did lie with me.

sp.speaker: Grati.
sp.l: Why this is like the mending of high ways
in Summer where the ways are fair enough?
What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Speak not so grossly, you are all amazed;
Here is a letter, read it at your leisure,
It comes from Padua from Bellario,
there you shall find that Portia was the Doctor,
Nerrissa there her Clarke. Lorenzo here
shall witness I set forth as soon as you,
and even but now returned: I have not yet
entered my house. Anthonio you are welcome,
and I have better news in store for you
than you expect: unseal this letter soon,
there you shall find three of your Argosies
are richly come to harbour suddenly.
You shall not know by what strange accident
I chanced on this letter.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I am dumb?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Were you the Doctor, and I knew you not?

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Were you the Clark that is to make me cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ner.
sp.l: Aye but the Clarke that never means to do it,
unless he live until he be a man.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: (Sweet Doctor) you shall be my bedfellow,
when I am absent then lie with my wife.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: (Sweet Lady) you have given me life and living;
for here I read for certain that my ships
are safely come to Rode.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How now Lorenzo?
my Clarke hath some good comforts too for you.

sp.speaker: Ner
sp.l: Aye, and I will give them him without a fee.
There do I give to you and Iessica
from the rich Jew, a special deed of gift
after his death, of all he dies possessed of.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Fair Ladies, you drop Manna in the way
of starved people.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: It is almost morning,
and yet I am sure you are not satisfied
of these events at full. Let us go in,
and charge us there upon interrogatories,
and we will answer all things faithfully.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Let it be so, the first interrogatory
that my Nerrissa shall be sworn on, is,
whether till the next night she had rather stay,
or go to bed now being two hours today:
But were the day come, I should wish it dark
till I were couching with the Doctors Clarke.
Well, while I live, I will fear no other thing
so sore, as keeping safe Nerrissas ring.
